summary: Bone cancer is an abnormal growth of tissue in bone, which can be benign or malignant. Malignant bone tumors can originate in the bone (primary) or spread from other parts of the body (secondary), with secondary tumors being significantly more common. Primary bone cancers include osteosarcoma, chondrosarcoma, and Ewing's sarcoma.
causes: Metastasis from other cancers (e.g., Lung cancer, Breast cancer, Thyroid cancer, Kidney cancer, Prostate cancer)
risk_factors: Age (10-19 years for Osteosarcoma and Ewing's sarcoma)
Presence of primary cancer in other organs (e.g., Lung, Breast, Thyroid, Kidney, Prostate)
symptoms: Pain (often worse at night and at rest)
treatments: Surgery (e.g., Limb amputation, Limb sparing surgery, Bone graft, Artificial bone replacement, Limb salvage prostheses, Allograft, Tumor-devitalized autograft, Vascularized fibula graft, Distraction osteogenesis, Custom-made implants)
subtypes: Pleomorphic undifferentiated sarcoma (formerly Malignant fibrous histiocytoma)
Germ cell tumors (e.g., Teratoma, Sacrococcygeal teratoma)
Other mesenchymal tumors of bone (WHO 2020 classification)
